title: Is focus order predictable, logical, and intuitive?
content:
### What this means When someone uses the keyboard to move through a page, typically by pressing the `Tab` key, the order in which interactive elements receive focus should make sense. Focus should follow the visual reading flow of the page. That usually means left to right and top to bottom. If the focus order jumps around unexpectedly or skips important elements, it makes the interface harder to use and understand. **ONLY** interactive elements should receive focus. Elements such as buttons, links, and form fields. Regular text should be skipped as it is not interactive. ### Why this matters Keyboard users do not experience the whole interface at once. They move through the interface one element at a time. If the focus order is unpredictable, users can get lost or miss key actions. That can result in a frustrating experience. For screen readers users, the focus order is also how content is announced. A logical, intuitive flow improves usability for these users. ### What this looks like

title: Are buttons, links, and other CTAs designed and implemented to consider both hover and focus states?
content:
## What this means

Interactive elements such as buttons, links, and calls to action must provide clear visual feedback for both mouse hover and keyboard focus states. Hover states support mouse and pointer users, while focus states support keyboard and assistive technology users.

Hover and focus are not the same interaction and should not be treated as interchangeable. Focus states must appear when an element receives keyboard focus, regardless of whether a mouse is present. Relying on hover styles alone is not sufficient.

## Why this matters

Keyboard users rely on focus styles to understand which element is currently active. If interactive elements only change appearance on hover, keyboard users may have no visual indication of where they are on the page.

When hover and focus states are inconsistent or missing, users can become disoriented, make mistakes, or be unable to complete tasks. This disproportionately affects keyboard-only users, screen reader users who rely on visual focus cues, and users with low vision.

Providing clear and equivalent hover and focus feedback ensures that all users receive the same interaction cues, regardless of input method.

## What to check for

* Do all interactive elements display a visible focus style when navigated to using the keyboard?
* Are hover styles for buttons, links, and CTAs also applied, or thoughtfully adapted, to focus states?
* Is the focus style clearly visible and distinct from the default state, not just a subtle color change?
* Does focus remain visible even when hover styles are present or when the mouse moves away?

## What to avoid

* Designing interaction feedback that appears only on hover and not on focus.
* Removing native focus styles without providing a clear and accessible replacement.
* Using focus styles that are too subtle to notice or that rely solely on color changes with low contrast.
* Treating hover and focus as the same state in design or code without verifying keyboard behavior.

## Related standards

* Blind users navigating with screen readers
* Power users who prefer keyboard shortcuts for efficiency
* Anyone whose pointing device has stopped working

Keyboard accessibility is fundamental to an inclusive digital experience.

title: Are we avoiding keyboard traps?
content:
## What this means

When someone navigates an interface using a keyboard, they must be able to move the focus through the entire page or into and out of every interactive component. A keyboard trap occurs when focus enters an element or region but cannot leave it using standard keyboard commands.

Users should be able to navigate freely using keys such as Tab, Shift + Tab, and Escape when appropriate. No component should capture focus in a way that prevents continued navigation.

Keyboard traps often occur in custom widgets, modals, menus, embedded content, or complex controls that are not implemented correctly.

## Why this matters

Keyboard users rely on predictable keyboard navigation to move through an interface. If focus becomes trapped, the user may be unable to reach other content or complete their task without reloading the page or switching input methods.

For screen reader users, a keyboard trap can completely block access to the rest of the interface. This creates a critical usability failure and can make the product unusable.

Avoiding keyboard traps is essential for maintaining basic operability and user control.

## What to check for

* Can focus move away from every interactive element using the keyboard alone?
* Can users exit modals, dialogs, menus, and overlays using standard keyboard interactions such as Tab, Shift + Tab, or Escape?
* When focus enters a complex component, is there a clear and reliable way to move focus out again?
* Do embedded widgets, iframes, or third party components allow keyboard users to exit them?

## What to avoid

* Components that trap focus without providing a keyboard method to exit.
* Custom controls that override native keyboard behavior without recreating it correctly.
* Requiring mouse interaction to escape a component.

title: Is the focus indicator clearly visible when active elements receive focus?
content:
## What this means

When someone navigates an interface using a keyboard, there must be a clear visual indicator showing which interactive element currently has focus. This is often referred to as the focus indicator or focus outline.

The focus indicator helps users understand where they are on the page as they move between links, buttons, form fields, and other interactive elements using keys such as Tab and Shift + Tab.

A visible focus indicator should be easy to see against surrounding content and should not be removed or obscured by custom styling..

## Why this matters

Keyboard users rely on the focus indicator to orient themselves within the interface. Without a visible indicator, users cannot tell which element will respond when they press Enter or Space.

For users with low vision, cognitive disabilities, or who are navigating quickly, a weak or missing focus indicator can make the interface confusing or unusable.

A clearly visible focus indicator supports efficient navigation, reduces errors, and reinforces user control over interactions.

## What to check for

* Is there a visible focus indicator on all interactive elements, including links, buttons, form fields, and custom controls?
* Does the focus indicator have sufficient contrast against the background and surrounding elements?
* Is the focus indicator still visible when custom styles, themes, or animations are applied?
* Does focus remain visible when navigating through complex components such as menus, dialogs, and toolbars?

## What to avoid

* Removing focus outlines without providing an equally visible custom alternative.
* Focus indicators that blend into the background or are too subtle to notice.
* Focus styles that only appear on mouse interaction but not during keyboard navigation.
* Focus indicators that are clipped, hidden, or covered by other UI elements.

title: Are errors described in text?
content:
## What this means

When an error occurs, it must be communicated using text. Users should be able to understand what went wrong without relying on color, icons, sound, or visual position alone.

Error text must be programmatically available so assistive technologies can announce it. The message should clearly identify the error and relate it to the affected input or action.

## Why this matters

Screen reader users cannot perceive visual cues such as red outlines or icons. Without text, errors may go unnoticed or be impossible to understand.

Text-based error descriptions also support users with low vision, color vision deficiencies, or cognitive disabilities. Clear messages reduce frustration and help users recover efficiently.

## What to check for

* Errors are described using clear, readable text.
* Error messages identify the specific problem.
* The error text is associated with the relevant field or action.
* Assistive technologies announce error messages when they appear.
* Errors are not conveyed by color or icons alone.

## What to avoid

* Indicating errors only with color, symbols, or sound.
* Displaying generic messages that do not explain the issue.
* Showing error states without any accompanying text.
* Placing error text where it is not programmatically related to the error.

## Related standards

title: Are form labels visible and persistent?
content:
## What this means

Form labels must be visible and remain present at all times. Users should be able to identify the purpose of each field before, during, and after interaction.

Labels should not disappear when a field receives focus or when input is entered. The label must remain available to support understanding and review.

## Why this matters

Screen reader users rely on labels to understand form fields consistently. If labels are hidden or removed, users may lose context when navigating or revisiting fields.

Visible and persistent labels also support users with cognitive disabilities, low vision, or memory impairments. They reduce errors and make forms easier to complete, correct, and verify.

## What to check for

* Each form control has a visible label at all times.
* Labels remain visible when the field is focused or filled.
* Floating labels do not obscure or replace the label text.
* Labels are not conveyed by placeholder text alone.
* The visible label matches the programmatic accessible name.

## What to avoid

* Labels that disappear on focus or after input.
* Using placeholder text as the only visible label.
* Revealing labels only on hover or focus.
* Relying on visual position or styling alone to convey meaning.

title: Are form labels meaningful?
content:
## What this means

Every form control must have a label that clearly describes its purpose. The label should communicate what information is required or what action the control performs.

Meaningful labels are provided through visible text or programmatic associations. This includes label elements, aria-label, or aria-labelledby when used correctly.

Screen reader users rely on labels to understand form fields. If labels are missing, vague, or incorrect, users may not know what data to enter.

Clear labels also support keyboard users and users with cognitive disabilities. They reduce errors and make forms easier to complete and review.

## What to check for

* Each form control has a programmatically associated label.
* Labels clearly describe the expected input or action.
* Required fields are indicated in a way that is accessible.
* Placeholder text is not used as a replacement for labels.
* Assistive technologies announce an accurate and specific label.

## What to avoid

* Missing labels or labels that are visually hidden without an accessible name.
* Generic labels such as “input” or “field.”
* Using only placeholder text to describe a field.
* Labels that do not match the actual purpose of the control.

title: Is real text used rather than images of text?
content:
## What this means

Text content should be implemented as actual text, not baked into images. Users must be able to resize, restyle, and access text through assistive technologies.

Images of text should only be used when the text presentation is essential to the information being conveyed. This is typically limited to logos or cases where no alternative is possible.

## Why this matters

Screen readers cannot interpret text embedded in images unless an accurate text alternative is provided. Even with alternatives, images of text reduce flexibility and usability.

Real text supports zooming, reflow, high contrast modes, and user-defined styles. It also improves readability for users with low vision, dyslexia, or cognitive disabilities.

## What to check for

* Headings, labels, instructions, and body content are implemented as text.
* Text can be resized without loss of content or functionality.
* Custom fonts and styles are applied using CSS, not images.
* Text remains readable in high contrast and forced color modes.
* Any image of text has an equivalent accessible text alternative.

## What to avoid

* Using images to display headings, paragraphs, or buttons.
* Embedding critical instructions or data in images.
* Relying on alt text to compensate for unnecessary images of text.
* Preventing users from resizing or restyling text.

* Links with the same destination use consistent text.

title: Are recurring navigation patterns and functionalities presented and labeled consistently throughout the system?
content:
## What this means

Recurring navigation patterns and shared functionalities should be presented in a consistent way wherever they appear. Users encounter the same structure, placement, and labeling for navigation and common actions across the system.

Consistency applies to how components look, how they behave, and how they are named. A control that performs the same function should not change its appearance, interaction, or label based on location.

Accessible names and programmatic labels follow the same consistency. Assistive technologies announce the same control using the same name and role across contexts.

## Why this matters

Users build mental models as they move through an interface. When navigation patterns or labels change unexpectedly, those models break and users must slow down to reorient themselves.

Inconsistent labeling can cause screen reader users to interpret identical actions as different controls. This increases cognitive load and can lead to errors or hesitation during task completion.

Consistent patterns support predictability and efficiency. They reduce the effort required to learn and use the interface, particularly for users with cognitive disabilities or those relying on assistive technologies.

## What to check for

* Navigation structures remain stable across pages that serve similar purposes.
* Identical actions use the same visible text and accessible name wherever they appear.
* Repeated components behave the same way for mouse, keyboard, and touch interactions.
* Icons representing the same function are paired with consistent text or accessible labels.
* Roles, states, and properties exposed to assistive technologies do not vary between instances.

## What to avoid

* Changing labels for the same action without a clear and necessary distinction.
* Moving or restructuring navigation in similar views without user benefit.
* Using different visual treatments to represent the same functionality.
* Implementing repeated components with different accessibility semantics.

* EN 301 549: 9.3.2.3 Consistent navigation
* EN 301 549: 9.3.2.4 Consistent identification
* WCAG 2.2: 3.2.3 Consistent Navigation
* WCAG 2.2: 3.2.4 Consistent Identification

title: Are adjacent links pointing to unique locations combined into a single CTA?
content:
## What this means

When multiple links or interactive elements are placed next to each other and all lead to the same destination or closely related destinations, they should be combined into a single, clear call to action.

Adjacent links that appear separate but perform the same action can create confusion about what is clickable and where an action will lead. It also creates unnecessary steps for keyboard users. A single, well defined CTA reduces ambiguity and simplifies interaction.

This applies to text links, buttons, icons, cards, headlines with links, and any other interactive elements that are visually grouped.

## Why this matters

Screen reader and keyboard users encounter each interactive element individually. When several adjacent links point to the same or similar destination, users may have to navigate through redundant options that do not provide additional value.

Redundant links increase cognitive load and slow down navigation. This makes it harder to understand the structure and purpose of the content. This can be especially frustrating for users who rely on keyboard navigation or screen reader link lists.

Combining adjacent links into a single CTA improves clarity and reduces unnecessary focus stops. This creates a more predictable and efficient experience for all users.

## What to check for

* Are there multiple adjacent links or clickable elements that navigate to the same page or perform the same action?
* Do linked headlines, images, and supporting text all point to the same destination without being grouped into a single interactive element?
* Can the number of focusable elements be reduced without removing meaningful choices?

## What to avoid

* Placing several links next to each other that all lead to the same destination.
* Making entire content blocks partially clickable while also including separate links inside them that perform the same action.
* Repeating the same CTA multiple times in close proximity without adding clarity or choice.
* Creating extra focus stops that do not provide additional information or control.

title: Is all content placed within a landmark or region?
content:
## What this means

Page content must be contained within appropriate landmarks or regions. Landmarks define the overall structure of the page and help users understand how content is organized.

Common landmarks include header, navigation, main, complementary, and footer. Custom regions may also be used when native landmarks are not sufficient.

## Why this matters

Screen reader users rely on landmarks to navigate pages efficiently. When content exists outside of landmarks, it may be harder to find or understand in context.

Landmarks also support keyboard users and users with cognitive disabilities. A clear structure improves orientation and reduces the effort required to move through content.

## What to check for

* All visible content is contained within a landmark or region.
* Each landmark has a clear and appropriate role.
* The main content is contained within a single main landmark.
* Repeated content uses consistent landmarks across pages.
* Assistive technologies can identify and navigate landmarks.

## What to avoid

* Placing content outside of any landmark or region.
* Using multiple main landmarks on the same page.
* Applying landmark roles purely for visual grouping.
* Creating regions without an accessible name when required.

title: Are buttons used for CTAs that trigger functionalities within the page?
content:
## What this means

Calls to action that trigger functionality on the current page should be implemented as buttons. The semantic role must match the behavior the user initiates.

Buttons are used for actions such as submitting a form, opening a dialog, toggling content, or updating data without navigating away.

Assistive technology users rely on semantics to understand what will happen when an element is activated. When buttons are correctly used, expectations are clear and interactions are predictable.

## What to check for

* CTAs that trigger in-page actions are implemented as buttons.
* Button semantics are preserved even when visually styled as links.
* Buttons expose an accessible name that describes the action.
* Assistive technologies announce the element as a button.
* Keyboard activation triggers the intended functionality.

## What to avoid

* Using links to trigger in-page functionality.
* Changing application state through elements exposed as links.
* Removing button semantics for visual styling purposes.
* Creating custom controls that do not expose the correct role.

* CTAs that navigate to another page are implemented as links.
* Link semantics are preserved even when styled as buttons.

* Changing location as a side effect of a button action.

title: Do section headings follow a hierarchical structure and do not skip any levels?
content:
## What this means

Headings must follow a logical, hierarchical order that reflects the structure of the content. Each heading level represents a clear relationship to the content that follows it.

## Why this matters

Screen reader users rely on headings to understand page structure and to navigate efficiently. Skipped or misordered headings make content harder to follow and interpret.

A consistent heading hierarchy also supports keyboard users and users with cognitive disabilities. Clear structure improves orientation and comprehension when scanning or navigating content.

## What to check for

* Headings are used to describe sections of content.
* Heading levels follow a logical and sequential order.
* No heading levels are skipped.
* Visual styling does not replace proper heading markup.
* Assistive technologies announce headings and their levels correctly.

## What to avoid

* Skipping heading levels to achieve visual styling.
* Using headings purely for presentation.
* Placing content under headings of an incorrect level.
* Creating a flat structure where all headings use the same level.

title: Are lists used to present groupings and enumerations?

* Lists are not broken by unrelated content.
* Nested lists reflect logical sub-groupings.
* Assistive technologies announce list structure correctly.

* Using line breaks or visual spacing instead of lists.
* Simulating lists with icons, numbers, or styling alone.
* Combining unrelated items into a single list.

* Every page has a programmatic title.
* The title accurately describes the page’s main content or function.
* Titles are unique across the site where pages serve different purposes.
* Dynamic pages update the title when the primary content changes.
* Assistive technologies announce the correct page title.

* Missing or empty page titles.
* Generic titles such as “Home” or “Page” without context.

* Descriptions are synchronized with the video.
* Audio descriptions do not overlap critical dialogue.
* On-screen text is included in the audio description when needed.
* Users can access the audio-described version of the video.

* Omitting descriptions of actions, scene changes, or visual cues.
* Providing descriptions that are incomplete or unclear.
* Assuming dialogue alone conveys all necessary context.

* Essential animations are limited and justified.

* Using motion when a static alternative would suffice.

title: Are target areas large enough?
content:
## What this means

Interactive targets must be large enough to be easily activated. This includes buttons, links, form controls, and other clickable or tappable elements.

Targets should provide sufficient size and spacing so users can activate them without precision or accidental activation of adjacent elements.

## Why this matters

Users with motor impairments may have limited fine motor control. Small or tightly spaced targets increase errors and make interaction frustrating.

Adequate target size also supports users on touch devices, users with tremors, and users in motion. Larger targets improve accuracy and ease of use for everyone.

## What to check for

* Interactive targets meet minimum size requirements.
* Sufficient spacing exists between adjacent targets.
* Targets remain usable at different zoom levels.
* Custom controls provide the same target size as native controls.
* Assistive technologies can activate targets reliably.

## What to avoid

* Very small clickable or tappable areas.
* Placing interactive elements too close together.
* Reducing target size for visual or layout reasons.
* Relying on precise pointer movement to activate controls.

## Related standards

title: Does pre-recorded audio-only and video-only content have a transcript?
content:
## What this means

Pre-recorded audio-only and video-only content must have a text transcript. The transcript provides all meaningful information conveyed through audio or visuals in text form.

* Audio-only content includes a complete text transcript.
* Video-only content includes a transcript describing visual information.
* Transcripts convey the same meaning as the original media.
* Transcripts are easy to locate and access.
* Assistive technologies can read the transcript content.

## What to avoid

* Providing media without any text alternative.
* Omitting meaningful sounds or visual details from transcripts.
* Relying on captions for audio-only content.
* Placing transcripts in formats that are not accessible.

title: Does text have sufficient color contrast with the background?
content:
## What this means

Text must have enough contrast against its background to be readable. Contrast is determined by the luminance difference between the text color and the background color.

Users with low vision or color vision deficiencies may not be able to read low-contrast text. Poor contrast also affects users in bright environments or on low-quality displays.

Sufficient contrast improves readability for all users. It reduces eye strain and supports comprehension across a wide range of viewing conditions.

## What to check for

* Text meets minimum contrast ratios against its background.
* Contrast is maintained across all states, including hover and focus.
* Text remains readable in high contrast and forced color modes.
* Background images do not reduce text readability.
* Icons that convey meaning meet contrast requirements.

## What to avoid

* Using low-contrast color combinations.
* Relying on color alone to convey information.
* Placing text over images without ensuring sufficient contrast.
* Reducing contrast for disabled or secondary text.

title: Does content require users to scroll both vertically and horizontally?
content:
## What this means

Content should not require users to scroll in two directions to read or interact with it. Users should be able to scroll in a single direction, typically vertically, at common viewport sizes.

Horizontal scrolling may be acceptable for specific components such as data tables or images when it is essential to the content. It should not be required for general reading or primary interactions.

## Why this matters

Users with low vision often zoom content to read it. When layouts force both horizontal and vertical scrolling, navigation becomes slow and disorienting.

Keyboard and screen reader users are also affected. Two-dimensional scrolling increases effort and can make it harder to understand content order and context.

## What to check for

* Content reflows to fit the viewport when zoomed.
* Horizontal scrolling is not required for body text or core interactions.
* Layouts adapt at smaller widths without truncation.
* Components that require horizontal scrolling are limited and intentional.
* Reading order remains logical when content reflows.

## What to avoid

* Fixed-width layouts that cause horizontal scrolling.
* Preventing content from wrapping when zoomed.
* Requiring horizontal scrolling for paragraphs or forms.
* Hiding content off screen without a clear way to access it.

title: Do informative images and complex graphs and charts have a meaningful accessible name?
content:
## What this means

Informative images, charts, and graphs must have an accessible name that clearly describes their purpose or content. The accessible name must convey the same meaningful information that is available visually.

* Assistive technologies announce the accessible name correctly.

* Hover and focus states reinforce link affordance.
* Visual cues are consistent across the interface.

* Relying on color differences alone to indicate links.
* Using link styling that closely matches body text.

* Content remains readable when line height is increased.
* Text does not overlap or clip when spacing is adjusted.
* Interactive elements remain usable with increased padding.
* Containers expand to accommodate increased spacing.
* No content or functionality is lost when custom spacing is applied.

## What to avoid

* Fixed heights that clip text when spacing changes.
* Absolute positioning that causes overlap.
* Preventing users from applying custom styles.
* Hiding overflow that conceals expanded content.

title: Are dynamically updated status messages announced without receiving visual focus?
content:
## What this means

Status messages that update dynamically must be announced to assistive technologies without moving visual focus. Users should receive important feedback without their current task being interrupted.

Status messages include confirmations, errors, progress updates, and other changes that are not the result of direct focus movement.

Screen reader users may not be aware of dynamic changes if they are not announced programmatically. Moving focus to announce a message can also be disruptive and confusing.

## What to check for

* Status messages are programmatically exposed to assistive technologies.
* Messages are announced without moving visual focus.
* Appropriate roles or properties are used for live updates.
* Announcements are concise and relevant to the user’s action.
* Repeated or unnecessary announcements are avoided.

## What to avoid

* Requiring focus to move in order to announce a status message.
* Displaying visual-only updates with no programmatic announcement.
* Announcing non-essential changes that interrupt the user.
* Using incorrect roles that cause unexpected focus behavior.

title: Do data tables have meaningful semantic column and row headers as well as a table name?
content:
## What this means

Data tables must use semantic markup to identify column headers, row headers, and a table name. Headers define how data cells relate to each other, and the table name provides overall context.

The table name is typically provided with a caption or an accessible name. Header cells are identified programmatically so relationships are exposed to assistive technologies.

## Why this matters

Screen reader users rely on table semantics to understand data relationships. Without headers or a table name, data may be announced without context or meaning.

Clear table structure also supports keyboard users and users with cognitive disabilities. It improves orientation, comprehension, and efficient navigation within tables.

## What to check for

* Data tables use semantic table markup.
* Column headers are marked as headers.
* Row headers are used where appropriate.
* The table has a meaningful name or caption.
* Assistive technologies can announce headers and table context.

## What to avoid

* Using tables for layout instead of data.
* Presenting data without semantic headers.
* Omitting a table name or caption.
* Relying on visual styling alone to indicate headers.

title: Is visual and auditory information presented in text format?
content:
## What this means

Information that is presented visually or audibly must also be available in text. Users should be able to access the same information without relying on sight or hearing.

Visual information includes icons, charts, animations, and visual cues. Auditory information includes sounds, spoken instructions, alerts, and audio-only feedback.

## Why this matters

Screen reader users cannot access visual-only information without text alternatives. Deaf or hard of hearing users cannot perceive auditory information without text.

Providing text equivalents also supports users with cognitive disabilities and users in environments where audio or visuals are limited or unavailable. Text ensures information is consistently accessible.

## What to check for

* Visual information has an equivalent text description.
* Audio information is available through captions, transcripts, or text messages.
* Instructions are not conveyed by sound or visuals alone.
* Text alternatives convey the same meaning as the original content.
* Assistive technologies can access the text version of the information.

## What to avoid

* Presenting instructions only through sound or visuals.
* Using icons or animations without accompanying text.
* Relying on audio cues without a text equivalent.
* Providing text that does not convey the full meaning of the information.
